thread.title: Prominent video gamer dies during 24-hour marathon livestream
thread.title_full: Prominent video gamer dies during 24-hour marathon livestream

author: CHRISTOPHER BRENNAN
title: Prominent video gamer dies during 24-hour marathon livestream
text:
NEW YORK DAILY NEWS  24 PM 
A prominent Virginia video gamer died during a 24-hour marathon gaming session he was streaming online to raise money for charity. 
Brian Vigneault, who went by the name Poshybrid online, had said that he would play for an entire day for the Make a Wish Foundation. 
However, he stepped away from his computer on Sunday for a cigarette around hour 22 and collapsed, Kotaku reported. 
Officers responded to a cardiac arrest call at 7:50 p.m. on Sunday, Virginia Beach Police told the Daily News, adding that foul play is not expected. Brian Vigneault died during a 24-hour charity video game marathon on Sunday. (Facebook) 
A cause and manner of his death are still pending, a Virginia Department of Health spokeswoman said. 
Fellow gamers said that Vigneault was fond of smoking, and it was not immediately clear if his gaming marathon contributed to his death. 
The 35-year-old father of three was broadcasting his exploits on the game World of Tanks via Twitch, an Amazon-owned social media platform that allows players to stream to their followers. Vigneault was broadcasting on the social media platform Twitch before his death. (© Robert Galbraith / Reuters/REUTERS) 
Vigneault had more than 9,000 followers as of Wednesday afternoon, and his page says that he has raised more than $10,000 for veterans’ and children’s charities through his streams. 
System Update: A look at the Nintendo Switch 
“We just can not find words to describe how sad is this moment for all of us and for sure this game will not be the same without the legend. Maybe the saddest lines can not really be written, and the saddest thoughts can not really be uttered,” posted a group of fellow gamers called FAME. 
An obituary for Vigneault said that he will be remembered at a memorial service on Tuesday. 
A moderator on his Twitch channel shared a GoFundMe page for his family that had raised more than $3,000 as of Wednesday afternoon. Tags:
